elements.content: Fluoroquinolone antibiotic (FQ) residues, such as ciprofloxacin (CIP) and ofloxacin (OFLX), have aroused public concerns owing to their serious impact in environmental water or food fields which influence human health. A facile and high-performance sensory method for detecting FQs is highly desirable for practical requirements. Herein, we have presented a luminescent Eu-MOF with unique 2D (4-c) {44.62}-connected topology, which holds the outstanding fluorescent property and excellent chemical stability in aqueous solution for 15 days. Thus, Eu-MOF can be considered as a highly sensitive chemo-sensor for sensing CIP and OFLX with different fluorescent color conversion (red changes to green for OFLX and to blue for CIP) and a low detection limit of 0.693 and 0.802 ppb, respectively. Furthermore, the mechanism of sensing CIP and OFLX was exposed to the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) and dynamic quenching process, as evaluated by DFT calculations and fluorescence lifetime decay measurements. Our work first reports a simple and efficient strategy for recognizing CIP and OFLX with a special luminescence color-change phenomenon based on MOF materials, serving as a meaningful guide for researchers in beneficial applications.
elements.clean_text:
Fluoroquinolone
antibiotic (FQ) residues, such as ciprofloxacin
(CIP) and ofloxacin (OFLX), have aroused public concerns owing to
their serious impact in environmental water or food fields which influence
human health. A facile and high-performance sensory method for detecting
FQs is highly desirable for practical requirements. Herein, we have
presented a luminescent Eu-MOF with unique 2D (4-c) {44.62}-connected topology, which holds the outstanding fluorescent
property and excellent chemical stability in aqueous solution for
15 days. Thus, Eu-MOF can be considered as a highly sensitive chemo-sensor
for sensing CIP and OFLX with different fluorescent color conversion
(red changes to green for OFLX and to blue for CIP) and a low detection
limit of 0.693 and 0.802 ppb, respectively. Furthermore, the mechanism
of sensing CIP and OFLX was exposed to the photoinduced electron transfer
(PET) and dynamic quenching process, as evaluated by DFT calculations
and fluorescence lifetime decay measurements. Our work first reports
a simple and efficient strategy for recognizing CIP and OFLX with
a special luminescence color-change phenomenon based on MOF materials,
serving as a meaningful guide for researchers in beneficial applications.

elements.content:
A highly stable luminescence Eu-MOF displays a unique color-transition and ultrasensitive fluorescence response toward CIP and OFLX, of which abuse will cause the drug resistance of some bacteria.

Introduction

Antibiotics, as a class of effective medicines, has evolved to prevent and treat diseases since the first antibiotic, penicillin, was discovered in 1928. In recent years, antibiotics have played an irreplaceable role in human medicine and food production due to their ability to inhibit the growth and reproduction of various pathogens. Up to now, there have been more than 160000 antibiotics developed and used popularly in various fields. Nevertheless, widespread application makes residual antibiotics exist in grains, groundwater, and animals’ bodies. Besides this, the abuse of antibiotics will inevitably cause bacterial drug resistance and negative effects such as allergic reactions, nephrotoxicity, and antibiotic resistance. Thereinto, ciprofloxacin (CIP) and ofloxacin (OFLX) are significant members of the group of fluoroquinolone (FQ) antibiotics and are used widely in the treatment of human and animal diseases, causing the large-scale production of these antibiotics and their gathering in the environment, which could pose severe risks on aquatic systems and human health. Over the past few years, many mature analytical techniques have been applied to detect antibiotics. For example, two isomeric In-MOFs, with high porosity and excellent stability, exhibit a strong fluorescence quenching effect to fluoroquinolone antibiotics. Besides this, a photodegradation method toward OFLX by UiO-67/CdS/rGO composites was researched by Wang and co-workers. In our contribution, we have first developed an ultrastable luminescent MOF (Eu-MOF) probe to multistimuli detect CIP and OFLX with low detection limits, rapid response time, and the interesting response phenomenon of a fluorescence ratiometric and color-transition mechanism.
elements.clean_text:
A highly stable luminescence Eu-MOF displays
a unique color-transition
and ultrasensitive fluorescence response toward CIP and OFLX, of which
abuse will cause the drug resistance of some bacteria.
Introduction
Antibiotics, as a class
of effective medicines, has evolved to
prevent and treat diseases since the first antibiotic, penicillin,
was discovered in 1928. In recent years,
antibiotics have played an irreplaceable role in human medicine and
food production due to their ability to inhibit the growth and reproduction
of various pathogens. Up to now, there have been more than 160000 antibiotics developed
and used popularly in various fields. Nevertheless, widespread application
makes residual antibiotics exist in grains, groundwater, and animals’
bodies. Besides this, the abuse of antibiotics will inevitably cause
bacterial drug resistance and negative effects such as allergic reactions,
nephrotoxicity, and antibiotic resistance. Thereinto, ciprofloxacin (CIP)
and ofloxacin (OFLX) are significant members of the group of fluoroquinolone
(FQ) antibiotics and are used widely in the treatment of human and
animal diseases, causing the large-scale production of these antibiotics
and their gathering in the environment, which could pose severe risks
on aquatic systems and human health. Over the past
few years, many mature analytical techniques have been applied to
detect antibiotics. For example, two isomeric In-MOFs, with high porosity and excellent
stability, exhibit a strong fluorescence quenching effect to fluoroquinolone
antibiotics. Besides this, a photodegradation
method toward OFLX by UiO-67/CdS/rGO composites was researched by
Wang and co-workers. In our contribution,
we have first developed an ultrastable luminescent MOF (Eu-MOF) probe
to multistimuli detect CIP and OFLX with low detection limits, rapid
response time, and the interesting response phenomenon of a fluorescence
ratiometric and color-transition mechanism.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a kind of two-or-three-dimensional porous material, are self-assembled by metal center ions or a cluster with organic ligands to extend infinite crystalline structures through coordination-type connections. Compared to other MOF materials, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have been meritoriously researched in the field of detection due to their characteristic luminescence properties. In the series of Ln-MOFs, we can obtain a luminescent multiemission property by tuning the energy transfer between the ligand and lanthanide ions, which provides a sensitive sensing platform with alterable fluorescent intensity and color. According to the coordination environment’s sensitivity of lanthanide ions, Ln-MOFs can serve as sensitive thermometers, pH indicators, and solvent probes to detect temperature, pH values, organic solvents, and other molecules. In addition, many advantages, such as high luminescence quantum yield, large Stokes shifts, and long-lived emission, are beneficial to detection applications.
elements.clean_text:
Metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), as a kind of two-or-three-dimensional
porous material, are self-assembled by metal center ions or a cluster
with organic ligands to extend infinite crystalline structures through
coordination-type connections. Compared to other MOF materials, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have
been meritoriously researched in the field of detection due to their
characteristic luminescence properties. In the series of Ln-MOFs,
we can obtain a luminescent multiemission property by tuning the energy
transfer between the ligand and lanthanide ions, which provides a
sensitive sensing platform with alterable fluorescent intensity and
color. According to the coordination environment’s
sensitivity of lanthanide ions, Ln-MOFs can serve as sensitive thermometers,
pH indicators, and solvent probes to detect temperature, pH values,
organic solvents, and other molecules. In addition, many advantages,
such as high luminescence quantum yield, large Stokes shifts, and
long-lived emission, are beneficial to detection applications.

elements.content: Bearing these in mind, a 2D (4-c) {44.62} net water-stable Eu-MOF is selected as an effective fluorescence probe to sense antibiotics in aqueous solution. For one, Eu-MOF possesses excellent chemical stability in water or at different pH values in aqueous solution and a characteristic photoluminescence phenomenon. For another, the pyrrole group of the ligand is free and can be used as active sites to react with specific chemicals. Based on the features mentioned above, Eu-MOF displays a unique flourescence response to two kinds of fluoroquinolone antibiotics, CIP and OFLX, with a fluorescence ratiometric and color-transition quenching mechanism. Moreover, the sensing of antibiotics exhibits an ultralow-level detection limit, broad detection range, and rapid response time with a peculiar color-change performance.
elements.clean_text:
Bearing these in mind, a 2D (4-c) {44.62}
net water-stable Eu-MOF is selected as an effective fluorescence probe
to sense antibiotics in aqueous solution. For one, Eu-MOF possesses
excellent chemical stability in water or at different pH values in
aqueous solution and a characteristic photoluminescence phenomenon.
For another, the pyrrole group of the ligand is free and can be used
as active sites to react with specific chemicals. Based on the features
mentioned above, Eu-MOF displays a unique flourescence response to
two kinds of fluoroquinolone antibiotics, CIP and OFLX, with a fluorescence
ratiometric and color-transition quenching mechanism. Moreover, the
sensing of antibiotics exhibits an ultralow-level detection limit,
broad detection range, and rapid response time with a peculiar color-change
performance.

elements.content: All chemicals and reagents used were commercially purchased and at least of analytical grade. PXRD patterns at diffraction angles from 5° to 50° were obtained with an Empyrean Panalytical apparatus. A Netzsch STA409pc apparatus was implemented for TGA curves with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 to 1400 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. All fluorescent spectra were obtained on a FL-970 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. The fluorescence decay time of compounds were collected on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer at room temperature. UV–vis spectra were carried out on a U-3900 spectrograph.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section
Materials
and Methods
All chemicals and reagents used
were commercially purchased and at least of analytical grade. PXRD
patterns at diffraction angles from 5° to 50° were obtained
with an Empyrean Panalytical apparatus. A Netzsch STA409pc apparatus
was implemented for TGA curves with a heating rate of 10 °C/min
from 30 to 1400 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. All fluorescent
spectra were obtained on a FL-970 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon
lamp as the excitation source. The fluorescence decay
time of compounds were collected on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer
at room temperature. UV–vis spectra were carried out on a U-3900
spectrograph.

elements.content: First, 0.12 mmol of EuCl3·6H2O and 0.05 mmol of H2PIA (H2PIA = 5-(1H-pyrazol-3-yl)­isophthalic acid) (Figure S1) was mixed into 10 mL of H2O. The pH value of the resulting solution was adjusted by adding 20 μL of HNO3 (1 M), and the mixture was sonicated for 30 min. The suspension was moved to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 72 h with 2 °C per hour cooling to 30 °C to generate block colorless crystals at a yield of 20.1% (based on EuCl3·6H2O). C22H16EuNO10: calcd C, 40.76; H, 2.48; N, 2.16. Found: C, 40.25; H, 2.511; N, 2.12. IR: 3409(s), 1871­(w), 1700­(w), 1553(s), 1388(s), 1236­(m), 1093­(m), 941­(m), 775­(m), 611­(w).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Eu-MOF
First, 0.12
mmol of EuCl3·6H2O and 0.05 mmol of H2PIA (H2PIA = 5-(1H-pyrazol-3-yl)­isophthalic acid)
(Figure S1) was mixed into 10 mL of H2O. The pH value of
the resulting solution was adjusted by adding 20 μL of HNO3 (1 M), and the mixture was sonicated for 30 min. The suspension
was moved to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated
to 140 °C for 72 h with 2 °C per hour cooling to 30 °C
to generate block colorless crystals at a yield of 20.1% (based on
EuCl3·6H2O). C22H16EuNO10: calcd C, 40.76; H, 2.48; N, 2.16. Found: C, 40.25;
H, 2.511; N, 2.12. IR: 3409(s), 1871­(w), 1700­(w), 1553(s), 1388(s),
1236­(m), 1093­(m), 941­(m), 775­(m), 611­(w).

elements.content: The as-synthesized sample Eu-MOF (1 mg) was immersed in 14 kinds of aqueous solution (3 mL) with different pH values, and the mixtures were sonicated for 15 min. The luminescence spectra were measured immediately. In order to explore the framework stability of Eu-MOF at different pH values in aqueous solution, a sample (15 mg) soaked in an aqueous solution of pH = 3, 5, 9, or 10 for 4 h was selected for the PXRD test. Moreover, fluorescence spectra and PXRD patterns of the sample immersed in aqueous solution for 15 days were also obtained to prove the high water stability of Eu-MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Chemical Stability Experiments
The as-synthesized sample
Eu-MOF (1 mg) was immersed in 14 kinds of aqueous solution (3 mL)
with different pH values, and the mixtures were sonicated for 15 min.
The luminescence spectra were measured immediately. In order to explore
the framework stability of Eu-MOF at different pH values in aqueous
solution, a sample (15 mg) soaked in an aqueous solution of pH = 3,
5, 9, or 10 for 4 h was selected for the PXRD test. Moreover, fluorescence
spectra and PXRD patterns of the sample immersed in aqueous solution
for 15 days were also obtained to prove the high water stability of
Eu-MOF.

elements.content: Before all luminescence sensing experiments, block samples were ground into powder by a mortar to enhance the dispersity in distilled water. A crystal suspension (0.5 mg mL–1) was prepared by mixing 10 mg of ground sample and 20 mL of distilled water, and then the mixture was stirred for 30 min cautiously before being divided into 1 mL dispersions. Then, 2 mL of varied selected antibiotics solutions (with concentration of 0.01 M), i.e., tetracyclines (oxytetracycline, OTC; tetracycline, TC), sulfonamides (sulfamethoxazole, STX), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, CIP; ofloxacin, OFLX), nitroimidazoles (metronidazole, MDZ), and chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP), was added into the Eu-MOF suspension and sonicated uniformly for several minutes for the luminescence measurements. Titration experiments were tested by drop-by-drop addition of analytes from 10–6 to 10–3 M into the mixture, and the corresponding emission spectra were collected afterward.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence-Sensing Experiments
Before all luminescence
sensing experiments, block samples were ground into powder by a mortar
to enhance the dispersity in distilled water. A crystal suspension
(0.5 mg mL–1) was prepared by mixing 10 mg of ground
sample and 20 mL of distilled water, and then the mixture was stirred
for 30 min cautiously before being divided into 1 mL dispersions.
Then,
2 mL of varied selected antibiotics solutions (with concentration
of 0.01 M), i.e., tetracyclines (oxytetracycline, OTC; tetracycline,
TC), sulfonamides (sulfamethoxazole, STX), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin,
CIP; ofloxacin, OFLX), nitroimidazoles (metronidazole, MDZ), and chloramphenicols
(chloramphenicol, CAP), was added into the Eu-MOF suspension and sonicated
uniformly for several minutes for the luminescence measurements. Titration
experiments were tested by drop-by-drop addition of analytes from
10–6 to 10–3 M into the mixture,
and the corresponding emission spectra were collected afterward.

processes.material mix: 10 mg of ground sample and 20 mL of distilled water
2 mL of varied selected antibiotics solutions (with concentration of 0.01 M)

elements.content: The fluorescence paper matrices were prepared by cutting filter paper into a circular pattern (diameter of 2 cm); then, fine powder Eu-MOF (10 mg) with different antibiotic suspensions (concentration of 0.01 M) was mixed homogeneously by sonication for 20 min, anointed on the circular filter paper, and dried at room temperature. About 1 h later, the test strips were irradiated under a 365 nm UV lamp, and the paper-based fluorescence chemo-sensor was synthesized successfully.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Paper-based Fluorescence Chemosensor
The
fluorescence paper matrices were prepared by cutting filter paper
into a circular pattern (diameter of 2 cm); then, fine powder Eu-MOF
(10 mg) with different antibiotic suspensions (concentration of 0.01
M) was mixed homogeneously by sonication for 20 min, anointed on the
circular filter paper, and dried at room temperature. About 1 h later,
the test strips were irradiated under a 365 nm UV lamp, and the paper-based
fluorescence chemo-sensor was synthesized successfully.

processes.material mix: Eu-MOF (10 mg) with different antibiotic suspensions (concentration of 0.01 M)

elements.content: Single-crystal data of Eu-MOF with suitable dimensions were corrected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD X-ray single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromic Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073) at 273.15 K. The diffraction data absorption was corrected by the SADABS program. The crystal structure of as-synthesized Eu-MOF was solved by the direct method through using the SHELXTL-97 and OLEX-2 interface programs, and the structure data were refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with anisotropic parameters. Hydrogen atoms were determined in ideal positions in theory by the riding model, and all non-hydrogen atoms were calculated with anisotropic displacement during the final cycles. The large disordered guest molecules in the pore of Eu-MOF were flattened using the AQUEEZE program of PLATON. The topological structure of Eu-MOF was analyzed by the TOPOS 4.0 software. The detailed crystallographic results and selected bond lengths and bond angles are summarized in Table S1 and Table S2 of the Supporting Information. Finally, information on Eu-MOF can be found with the CCDC number 1988050.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal
X-ray Analysis
Single-crystal data of
Eu-MOF with suitable dimensions were corrected on a Bruker APEX-II
CCD X-ray single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromic
Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073) at 273.15 K.
The diffraction data absorption was corrected by the SADABS program.
The crystal structure of as-synthesized Eu-MOF was solved by the direct
method through using the SHELXTL-97 and OLEX-2 interface programs,
and the structure data were refined by full-matrix least-squares on F

2
 with anisotropic parameters.
Hydrogen atoms were determined in ideal positions in theory by the
riding model, and all non-hydrogen atoms were calculated with anisotropic
displacement during the final cycles. The large disordered guest molecules
in the pore of Eu-MOF were flattened using the AQUEEZE program of
PLATON. The topological structure of Eu-MOF was analyzed by the TOPOS
4.0 software. The detailed crystallographic results and selected bond
lengths and bond angles are summarized in Table S1 and Table S2 of the Supporting Information. Finally, information
on Eu-MOF can be found with the CCDC number 1988050.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis evidently revealed that Eu-MOF crystallizes in the triclinic crystallographic system with the P1̅ space group. One PIA2– ligand, one HPIA– ligand, one crystallographic independent Eu3+ ion, and two coordinated H2O were contained in the asymmetric unit. The bond lengths between the Eu and O atoms are in the range 2.303–2.517 Å, and the bond angles of O–Eu–O range from 52.26° to 149.83°, which is well matched to the relative literature. As shown in a, the Eu3+ ion accords with eight-coordinated oxygen atoms in which O10 and O8 originate from two coordinated H2O molecules, O3, O4, and O5 from two ligands with different coordinate modes exhibited in Figure S2a and S2b. One eight-coordinated Eu3+ ion with a coordinated carboxylate further forms a metal–carboxylate chain as a secondary building unit (SBUs). The H2PIA ligand is connected with two [Eu­(COO)2] n SBUs to generate a 2D cross-lamellated structure (b). Then, with the connection modes between the H2PIA ligand and [Eu­(COO)2] n SBUs, the 2D cross-lamellated structure further expands the network chains exhibited in c. Moreover, owing to the intricate structure of Eu-MOF, the topology of the underlying net was explored by responding to the TOPOS 4.0 software. Through the deconstruction of crystalline networks, with each Eu3+ ion and PIA2– ligand, as the 4-connected (4-c) nodes, a 2D unimodal net with a {44.62} point symbol was established naturally. The whole node description is displayed in d.
elements.clean_text:
Results
and Discussion
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction of Eu-MOF
Single-crystal
X-ray diffraction analysis evidently revealed that Eu-MOF crystallizes
in the triclinic crystallographic system with the P1̅ space group. One PIA2– ligand, one HPIA– ligand, one crystallographic independent Eu3+ ion, and two coordinated H2O were contained in the asymmetric
unit. The bond lengths between the Eu and O atoms are in the range
2.303–2.517 Å, and the bond angles of O–Eu–O
range from 52.26° to 149.83°, which is well matched to the
relative literature. As shown in a, the Eu3+ ion accords with eight-coordinated oxygen
atoms in which O10 and O8 originate from two coordinated H2O molecules, O3, O4, and O5 from two ligands with different coordinate
modes exhibited in Figure S2a and S2b.
One eight-coordinated Eu3+ ion with a coordinated carboxylate
further forms a metal–carboxylate chain as a secondary building
unit (SBUs). The H2PIA ligand is connected with two [Eu­(COO)2]
n
 SBUs to generate a 2D cross-lamellated
structure (b). Then, with the connection modes between the H2PIA
ligand and [Eu­(COO)2]
n
 SBUs,
the 2D cross-lamellated structure further expands the network chains
exhibited in c. Moreover, owing to the intricate structure of Eu-MOF, the topology
of the underlying net was explored by responding to the TOPOS 4.0
software. Through the deconstruction of crystalline networks, with
each Eu3+ ion and PIA2– ligand, as the
4-connected (4-c) nodes, a 2D unimodal net with a {44.62} point symbol was established naturally. The whole node description
is displayed in d.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetrical unit of Eu-MOF: (#1) 1 – x, −y, 1 – z and (#2) 1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) 2D lamellated structure of Eu-MOF from the direction of the c and a axis, respectively. (c) 2D network structure of Eu-MOF. (d) The (4-c) net topology structure of Eu-MOF.
elements.clean_text:
1

(a) The asymmetrical unit of Eu-MOF: (#1) 1 – x, −y, 1 – z and (#2)
1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) 2D lamellated structure of Eu-MOF from the direction of the c and a axis, respectively. (c) 2D network
structure of Eu-MOF. (d) The (4-c) net topology structure of Eu-MOF.

elements.content: First, the phase purity of the Eu-MOF was investigated by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Figure S3, the experimental pattern of Eu-MOF is in good agreement with the simulated one obtained from the Mercury program, indicative of the excellent phase purity and crystalline nature of Eu-MOF. Second, representative FT-IR spectra of as-synthesized Eu-MOF and H2PIA in the range of 4000 to 450 cm–1 are listed in Figure S4 for comparison; the IR band at 1604 cm–1 for the H2PIA (νCO) was shifted to 1553 cm–1, proving that the carboxyl group of H2PIA was deprotonated and coordinated with Eu3+ ions. Third, therogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed from 30 to 1400 °C to evaluate the thermal stability of Eu-MOF. Figure S5 displays that Eu-MOF loses the two coordinated water molecules at two steps from 170 to 310 °C with the weight loss of 2.9% (calculated 2.8%), respectively. The whole crystal structure was still stable up to 490 °C, demonstrating an outstanding thermal stability. Finally, the structural stability of Eu-MOF after dehydration was explored by a PXRD test. As shown in Figure S6, the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated sample is well matched with that of the original sample, displaying that the structural framework remains stable after solvent removal.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Property of Eu-MOF
First, the
phase purity of the Eu-MOF was investigated by powder X-ray diffraction
analysis. As shown in Figure S3, the experimental
pattern of Eu-MOF is in good agreement with the simulated one obtained
from the Mercury program, indicative of the excellent phase purity
and crystalline nature of Eu-MOF. Second, representative FT-IR spectra
of as-synthesized Eu-MOF and H2PIA in the range of 4000
to 450 cm–1 are listed in Figure S4 for comparison; the IR band at 1604 cm–1 for the H2PIA (νCO) was shifted
to 1553 cm–1, proving that the carboxyl group of
H2PIA was deprotonated and coordinated with Eu3+ ions. Third, therogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed from
30 to 1400 °C to evaluate the thermal stability of Eu-MOF. Figure S5 displays that Eu-MOF loses the two
coordinated water molecules at two steps from 170 to 310 °C with
the weight loss of 2.9% (calculated 2.8%), respectively. The whole
crystal structure was still stable up to 490 °C, demonstrating
an outstanding thermal stability. Finally, the structural stability
of Eu-MOF after dehydration was explored by a PXRD test. As shown
in Figure S6, the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated
sample is well matched with that of the original sample, displaying
that the structural framework remains stable after solvent removal.

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescence properties of the Eu-MOF and free H2PIA (both amounts are 10 mg) are first investigated at ambient temperature. Upon excitation with a wavelength of 330 nm, the emission spectrum of free H2PIA shows broad bands at 395 nm, which can be ascribed to the intramolecular π–π* electron transition between the π-bonding orbital and π*-antibonding orbital (a). The fluorescence properties of Eu-MOF exhibit a typical Eu3+ ion luminescence color under portable UV lamp irradiation with shape and well-separated emission bands. As shown in b, Eu-MOF shows four well-resolved emission peaks at 590, 614, 643, and 696 nm (λex = 321 nm), which are corresponded to 5D0–7F J (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu3+ ions, respectively. Moreover, it is worth noting that the broad emission of H2PIA in the range of 350–450 nm nearly disappears entirely in the whole emission spectrum of Eu-MOF, indicating the high performance of the antenna effect, which demonstrates that H2PIA is an efficient antenna chromophore and demonstrates the occurrence of excellent energy transfer from the sensitizer (H2PIA) to central Eu3+ ions (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties
The solid-state photoluminescence
properties of the Eu-MOF and free H2PIA (both amounts are
10 mg) are first investigated at ambient temperature. Upon excitation
with a wavelength of 330 nm, the emission spectrum of free H2PIA shows broad bands at 395 nm, which can be ascribed to the intramolecular
π–π* electron transition between the π-bonding
orbital and π*-antibonding orbital (a). The fluorescence properties of Eu-MOF exhibit a typical Eu3+ ion luminescence color under portable UV lamp irradiation with shape
and well-separated emission bands. As shown in b, Eu-MOF shows four well-resolved emission
peaks at 590, 614, 643, and 696 nm (λex = 321 nm),
which are corresponded to 5D0–7F
J
 (J = 1, 2, 3, 4)
transitions of Eu3+ ions, respectively. Moreover, it is
worth noting that the broad emission of H2PIA in the range
of 350–450 nm nearly disappears entirely in the whole emission
spectrum of Eu-MOF, indicating the high performance of the antenna
effect, which demonstrates that H2PIA is an efficient antenna
chromophore and demonstrates the occurrence of excellent energy transfer
from the sensitizer (H2PIA) to central Eu3+ ions
(Figure S7).

elements.content: (a, b) The solid-state fluorescence spectra of H2PIA and Eu-MOF (excitation wavelength of 330 and 321 nm, respectively); (c) fluorescence relative intensity at 614 nm of Eu-MOF in solutions with different pH values; and (d) fluorescence spectra of Eu-MOF and the sample immersed in water for 15 days.
elements.clean_text:
2

(a, b) The
solid-state fluorescence spectra of H2PIA
and Eu-MOF (excitation wavelength of 330 and 321 nm, respectively);
(c) fluorescence relative intensity at 614 nm of Eu-MOF in solutions
with different pH values; and (d) fluorescence spectra of Eu-MOF and
the sample immersed in water for 15 days.

elements.content: Further, the fluorescence stability of Eu-MOF in aqueous solution for 15 days and at various pH values in solution was tested. The powder sample of Eu-MOF was soaked in a series of solutions with pH from 1 to 14; after ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min, fluorescence emission spectra analyses were carried out. Almost no distinct differences of both fluorescence spectra and PXRD patterns of Eu-MOF in the pH range of 3–10 were observed (c and Figure S8). Meanwhile, not only did the the intensity of the emission peaks of Eu-MOF remain stable after immersing Eu-MOF into aqueous solution for 15 days but also the PXRD pattern agrees well with that of the simulated Eu-MOF (d and Figure S9). Taken together, the above results imply that Eu-MOF possesses prominent stability for both fluorescence properties and crystal stability for a wide pH range, even in aqueous solution for a long time.
elements.clean_text:
Further, the fluorescence stability of Eu-MOF
in aqueous solution for 15 days and at various pH values in solution
was tested. The powder sample of Eu-MOF was soaked in a series of
solutions with pH from 1 to 14; after ultrasonic dispersion for 10
min, fluorescence emission spectra analyses were carried out. Almost
no distinct differences of both fluorescence spectra and PXRD patterns
of Eu-MOF in the pH range of 3–10 were observed (c and Figure S8). Meanwhile, not only did the the intensity of the emission
peaks of Eu-MOF remain stable after immersing Eu-MOF into aqueous
solution for 15 days but also the PXRD pattern agrees well with that
of the simulated Eu-MOF (d and Figure S9). Taken
together, the above results imply that Eu-MOF possesses prominent
stability for both fluorescence properties and crystal stability for
a wide pH range, even in aqueous solution for a long time.

elements.content: Antibiotics, as a class of medicines in human and animal health, are widely considered as serious organic pollutants. In view of the intense fluorescence properties and high stability of Eu-MOF, the detection application toward to a variety of antibiotics was explored. A total of seven common antibiotics from five classes, including tetracyclines (tetracycline, TC; oxytetracycline, OTC), sulfonamides (sulfamethoxazole, STX), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, CIP; ofloxacin, OFLX), nitroimidazoles (metronidazole, MDZ), and chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP), were tested. According to a, all of the selected antibiotics exhibit the same obvious fluorescence quenching to the sensor. More interestingly, it is evidently shown in the inset of a, that, among all of the fluorescence quenching response phenomena, fluoroquinolone antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, CIP; ofloxacin, OFLX) present a unique color transition differing from other fluorescence quenching caused by the other antibiotics, in which the photoluminescence of Eu-MOF changes from red to blue and to green for CIP and OFLX, respectively (b and c). What’s more, fluorescence-based test papers were also explored and displayed naked-eye color transition for CIP and OFLX (Figure S14). Thus, this indicates that Eu-MOF can be considered as a promising MOF-based fluorescent color-changing responsive chemo-sensor, which is convenient for practical recognition of CIP and OFLX.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Antibiotics
Antibiotics, as a class of
medicines in human and animal health, are widely considered as serious
organic pollutants. In view of the intense
fluorescence properties and high stability of Eu-MOF, the detection
application toward to a variety of antibiotics was explored. A total
of seven common antibiotics from five classes, including tetracyclines
(tetracycline, TC; oxytetracycline, OTC), sulfonamides (sulfamethoxazole,
STX), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, CIP; ofloxacin, OFLX), nitroimidazoles
(metronidazole, MDZ), and chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP),
were tested. According to a, all of the selected antibiotics exhibit the same
obvious fluorescence quenching to the sensor. More interestingly,
it is evidently shown in the inset of a, that, among all of the fluorescence quenching
response phenomena, fluoroquinolone antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, CIP;
ofloxacin, OFLX) present a unique color transition differing from
other fluorescence quenching caused by the other antibiotics, in which
the photoluminescence of Eu-MOF changes from red to blue and to green
for CIP and OFLX, respectively (b and c). What’s more,
fluorescence-based test papers were also explored and displayed naked-eye
color transition for CIP and OFLX (Figure S14). Thus, this indicates that Eu-MOF can be considered as a promising
MOF-based fluorescent color-changing responsive chemo-sensor, which
is convenient for practical recognition of CIP and OFLX.

elements.content: (a) The fluorescence spectra of Eu-MOF in different antibiotics solutions. (b, c) The fluorescence spectra comparison between Eu-MOF and that immersed in CIP and OFLX, respectively (insert images: the optical luminescence graph of Eu-MOF in different antibiotics solutions).
elements.clean_text:
3

(a) The fluorescence
spectra of Eu-MOF in different antibiotics
solutions. (b, c) The fluorescence spectra comparison between Eu-MOF
and that immersed in CIP and OFLX, respectively (insert images: the
optical luminescence graph of Eu-MOF in different antibiotics solutions).

elements.content: To further assess the sensing sensitivity of Eu-MOF for detecting two kinds of quinolone antibiotics, quantitative fluorescence titration experiments were performed with different concentrations of OFLX and CIP aqueous solutions, which were drop-by-drop added to the sample suspension (1 mg/mL). As shown in a and c, with the incremental addition of CIP and OFLX, the emission intensity at 614 nm decreased dramatically, while at 450 and 500 nm, it increased gradually, featuring heavy dependence on the variation of antibiotics’ concentration. According to the CIE coordinates listed in Table S3 and Figure S10, the luminescence color of Eu-MOF-CIP and Eu-MOF-OFLX exhibits a different and obvious color transition from red to blue and to green, respectively. The relationship between fluorescence quenching efficiency and the concentration of analytes can be fitted to the Stern–Volmer equation: (I 0 – I)/I 0 = 1 + K SV × [C], where I 0 and I are the emission intensity at 614 nm in the absence or presence of analytes, respectively, K SV is the quenching constant, and [C] is the concentration of antibiotics. Obviously, the SV plots for CIP and OFLX all display good linear correlation at low concentrations with the high K SV values of 22407 and 22751 M–1, respectively. Based on the K SV values, the detection limits of Eu-MOF toward CIP and OFLX could be calculated to be 0.693 and 0.802 ppb, respectively, according to the formula of LOD = 3σ/K, where σ = 100 × (S/I 0) (S is the standard deviation of (I 0 – I)/I 0 and K is the slope of the calibration curve), which is superior to the most reported fluorescence chemo-sensors for the above antibiotics based on MOFs (Table S4). Besides this, because of the rise (H2PIA) and fall (Eu3+ ions center) of fluorescence intensity, the fluorescence ratiometric detection was analyzed for CIP and OFLX based on I 450/I 614 and I 500/I 614, respectively. The results are shown in Figure S11; the relationship between the fluorescence intensity ratio (I 450/I 614 and I 500/I 614) and the concentration of analytes can be fitted to a quadratic nonlinear curve fit in the whole concentration range with a fitting correlation coefficient of 0.9959 and 0.9993 for CIP and OFLX, respectively. Therefore, the detection of CIP and OFLX reaches a remarkable fluorescence color-transition phenomenon with the different ratios of fluorescence intensity.

To further assess the sensing sensitivity of Eu-MOF
for detecting
two kinds of quinolone antibiotics, quantitative fluorescence titration
experiments were performed with different concentrations of OFLX and
CIP aqueous solutions, which were drop-by-drop added to the sample
suspension (1 mg/mL). As shown in a and c, with the
incremental addition of CIP and OFLX, the emission intensity at 614
nm decreased dramatically, while at 450 and 500 nm, it increased gradually,
featuring heavy dependence on the variation of antibiotics’
concentration. According to the CIE coordinates listed in Table S3 and Figure S10, the luminescence color of Eu-MOF-CIP and Eu-MOF-OFLX exhibits a
different and obvious color transition from red to blue and to green,
respectively. The relationship between fluorescence quenching efficiency
and the concentration of analytes can be fitted to the Stern–Volmer
equation: (I
0 – I)/I
0 = 1 + K
SV × [C], where I

absence or presence of analytes, respectively, K
SV is the quenching constant, and [C] is the
concentration of antibiotics. Obviously, the SV plots for CIP and
OFLX all display good linear correlation at low concentrations with
the high K
SV values of 22407 and 22751
M–1, respectively. Based on the K
SV values, the detection limits of Eu-MOF toward CIP and
OFLX could be calculated to be 0.693 and 0.802 ppb, respectively,
according to the formula of LOD = 3σ/K, where
σ = 100 × (S/I
0) (S is the standard deviation of (I
0 – I)/I
0 and K is the slope of the calibration curve),
which is superior to the most reported fluorescence chemo-sensors
for the above antibiotics based on MOFs (Table S4). Besides this, because of the rise (H2PIA) and
fall (Eu3+ ions center) of fluorescence intensity, the
fluorescence ratiometric detection was analyzed for CIP and OFLX based
on I
450/I

614, respectively. The results are shown in Figure S11; the relationship between the fluorescence intensity ratio
(I
450/I
614 and I
500/I
614) and the concentration of analytes can be fitted to a quadratic
nonlinear curve fit in the whole concentration range with a fitting
correlation coefficient of 0.9959 and 0.9993 for CIP and OFLX, respectively.
Therefore, the detection of CIP and OFLX reaches a remarkable fluorescence
color-transition phenomenon with the different ratios of fluorescence

elements.content: (a, c) Fluorescence emission spectra of Eu-MOF in different concentrations of CIP and OFLX solutions. (b, d) The Stern–Volmer plots of Eu-MOF in CIP and OFLX solutions.

4

(a, c) Fluorescence emission spectra of Eu-MOF in different concentrations
of CIP and OFLX solutions. (b, d) The Stern–Volmer plots of
Eu-MOF in CIP and OFLX solutions.

elements.content: In addition, the response time is also a decisive aspect to be investigated. The detecting emission spectra were measured at a regular interval of 30 s and 500 μL, presenting a quick response time of only an interval, and the relative emission intensity has a minor change for a further 180 s (Figure S13). Considering the practicability of the Eu-MOF fluorescence probe, the fluorescence-based test papers were built and applied in the detection field. As shown in Figure S14, the fluorescence-paper chemo-sensor immersed in different antibiotic suspensions exhibited different color changes, wherein the fluorescence color of CIP and OFLX is blue and green, respectively, differing from the red of the pristine Eu-MOF test paper. The above experimental results demonstrate that Eu-MOF possesses a color transition response, high sensitivity, and rapid response time for antibiotic detection applications.
elements.clean_text:
In addition, the response time is also a decisive aspect to be
investigated. The detecting emission spectra were measured at a regular
interval of 30 s and 500 μL, presenting a quick response time
of only an interval, and the relative emission intensity has a minor
change for a further 180 s (Figure S13).
Considering the practicability of the Eu-MOF fluorescence probe, the
fluorescence-based test papers were built and applied in the detection
field. As shown in Figure S14, the fluorescence-paper
chemo-sensor immersed in different antibiotic suspensions exhibited
different color changes, wherein the fluorescence color of CIP and
OFLX is blue and green, respectively, differing from the red of the
pristine Eu-MOF test paper. The above experimental results demonstrate
that Eu-MOF possesses a color transition response, high sensitivity,
and rapid response time for antibiotic detection applications.

elements.content: The luminescence sensing mechanism for fluoroquinolone antibiotics is a significant part to gaining insight into the detectability of Eu-MOF. According to previous literature reports, the collapse of structure, guest energy absorption, and electron transfer are the main reasons resulting in the fluorescence quenching mechanism. Primarily, the pivotal peak positions in the PXRD pattern of the sample after sensing experiments are well matched with those of pristine ones, proving that the damage to the framework is not the main reason for luminescence change (Figure S15). Next, the UV–vis absorption spectra of selective antibiotics and excitation wavelength were compared and are displayed in Figure S16; the UV–vis spectra of both CIP and OFLX have few overlaps between the absorption and excitation wavelength, demonstrating that the energy absorption of CIP and OFLX is a negligible reason for the fluorescence color change and quenching. More importantly, to verify the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) hypothesis, the LUMO and HOMO energy levels were calculated using DFT at the theoretical level of B3LYP/6-31G*. As can be seen in Figure S17, the LUMO energy levels of CIP and OFLX are higher than that of H2PIA ligand, reaching a possibility of electron transfer from the LUMO of OFLX and CIP to the LUMO of Eu-MOF, generating a fluorescence quenching of the Eu3+ ion centers. Finally, the luminescence properties of OFLX and CIP solutions shown in Figure S18 exhibited an emission peak at 500 and 450 nm, as derived from the intrinsic luminescence of OFLX and CIP. Meanwhile, the fluorescence kinetics process is explored also. On the one hand, fluorescence lifetime decay fitting curves exhibit that the emission at 614 nm is reduced dramatically after detecting CIP and OFLX. This is powerful evidence for the dynamic quenching process during fluorescence quenching (Figure S19). On the other hand, the relationship between luminescent intensity and concentration of CIP and OFLX deviate from the linear Stern–Volmer plot, further explaining the dynamic quenching mechanism in whole fluorescence detection experiments (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text:
Sensing
Mechanism
The luminescence sensing mechanism
for fluoroquinolone antibiotics is a significant part to gaining insight
into the detectability of Eu-MOF. According to previous literature
reports, the collapse of structure, guest energy absorption, and electron
transfer are the main reasons resulting in the fluorescence quenching
mechanism. Primarily, the pivotal peak positions in the PXRD pattern of the
sample after sensing experiments are well matched with those of pristine
ones, proving that the damage to the framework is not the main reason
for luminescence change (Figure S15). Next,
the UV–vis absorption spectra of selective antibiotics and
excitation wavelength were compared and are displayed in Figure S16; the UV–vis spectra of both
CIP and OFLX have few overlaps between the absorption and excitation
wavelength, demonstrating that the energy absorption of CIP and OFLX
is a negligible reason for the fluorescence color change and quenching.
More importantly, to verify the photoinduced electron transfer (PET)
hypothesis, the LUMO and HOMO energy levels were calculated using
DFT at the theoretical level of B3LYP/6-31G*. As can be seen in Figure S17, the LUMO energy levels of CIP and
OFLX are higher than that of H2PIA ligand, reaching a possibility
of electron transfer from the LUMO of OFLX and CIP to the LUMO of
Eu-MOF, generating a fluorescence quenching of the Eu3+ ion centers. Finally, the luminescence properties of OFLX and
CIP solutions shown in Figure S18 exhibited
an emission peak at 500 and 450 nm, as derived from the intrinsic
luminescence of OFLX and CIP. Meanwhile, the fluorescence kinetics
process is explored also. On the one hand, fluorescence lifetime decay
fitting curves exhibit that the emission at 614 nm is reduced dramatically
after detecting CIP and OFLX. This is powerful evidence for the dynamic
quenching process during fluorescence quenching (Figure S19). On the other hand, the relationship between luminescent
intensity and concentration of CIP and OFLX deviate from the linear
Stern–Volmer plot, further explaining the dynamic quenching
mechanism in whole fluorescence detection experiments (Figure S12).

elements.content: In conclusion, an ultrastable Eu-MOF, with the unprecedented 2D (4-c)­{44.62} topology framework, has been designed and synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method. With the outstanding chemical stability the Eu-MOF endows, it can be regarded as an ultrasensitive color-changing chemo-sensor to detect fluoroquinolone antibiotics (0.693 and 0.802 ppb for CIP and OFLX, respectively) in practical applications. Furthermore, the potential mechanisms of detecting fluoroquinolone antibiotics were researched with the help of DFT calculations and optical spectroscopy (UV–vis and luminescence spectra). Fortunately, we have first reported an easy-to-operate and inexpensive MOF-based material as a prototypical chemo-sensor to unambiguously recognize CIP and OFLX antibiotics with a high sensitivity, low detection limit, and unique color conversion luminescence phenomenon. This work also provides a novel approach to fabricate fluorescence sensory materials toward antibiotics in some important applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In
conclusion, an ultrastable Eu-MOF, with the unprecedented 2D
(4-c)­{44.62} topology framework, has been designed
and synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method. With the outstanding
chemical stability the Eu-MOF endows, it can be regarded as an ultrasensitive
color-changing chemo-sensor to detect fluoroquinolone antibiotics
(0.693 and 0.802 ppb for CIP and OFLX, respectively) in practical
applications. Furthermore, the potential mechanisms of detecting fluoroquinolone
antibiotics were researched with the help of DFT calculations and
optical spectroscopy (UV–vis and luminescence spectra). Fortunately,
we have first reported an easy-to-operate and inexpensive MOF-based
material as a prototypical chemo-sensor to unambiguously recognize
CIP and OFLX antibiotics with a high sensitivity, low detection limit,
and unique color conversion luminescence phenomenon. This work also
provides a novel approach to fabricate fluorescence sensory materials
toward antibiotics in some important applications.

metadata.title:
Stable Europium-based Metal–Organic Frameworks
for Naked-eye Ultrasensitive Detecting Fluoroquinolones Antibiotics
